title: Understanding the Cycle of Harm
summary: A gentle explanation of common patterns that can appear in unhealthy relationships.
body: Many people experience repeating behaviors in relationships that can feel confusing or overwhelming. This article explores these patterns in a supportive and non-judgmental way, helping readers recognize them and understand that they are not at fault.
author: Support Team

title: How to Create a Personal Safety Plan
summary: A supportive guide to planning for safety in difficult situations.
body: A safety plan is a personalized, practical plan that can help someone remain safe in situations where they feel uncertain or afraid. This article gently walks through what can be included, and encourages readers to move at their own pace.
author: Support Team

title: Recognizing Early Signs of Emotional Harm
summary: Subtle indicators that something may not feel right in a relationship.
body: Emotional harm can appear quietly and gradually. This article highlights gentle reminders to check in with yourself, trust your feelings, and seek support when something feels off.
author: Wellbeing Writer

title: Supporting a Friend Who May Be Struggling
summary: How to offer gentle support without pressure.
body: Many people want to help loved ones who may be going through difficult times but aren't sure how. This article provides suggestions on listening, validating, and respecting boundaries.
author: Support Team

title: Understanding Your Rights
summary: A gentle overview of legal protections available to survivors.
body: Legal language can be overwhelming. This article breaks down key rights and protections in simple, supportive terms.
author: Legal Support Team

title: Setting Healthy Boundaries
summary: Understanding boundaries and how to express them.
body: Boundaries are an essential part of wellbeing. This article introduces the idea of boundaries and supports readers in identifying what feels comfortable for them.
author: Wellbeing Writer

title: How Community Services Can Help
summary: A look at available community-based support resources.
body: Community organizations play an important role in providing emotional support, information, and referrals. This article outlines the types of help available.
author: Support Team

title: Digital Safety Tips
summary: Staying safe online while seeking information or support.
body: This article provides gentle and practical suggestions for maintaining privacy when using digital devices.
author: Support Team

title: Finding Strength After Difficult Experiences
summary: A reflective piece on resilience and healing.
body: Healing looks different for everyone. This article offers encouragement and insights for navigating emotional recovery.
author: Wellbeing Writer

title: How to Talk to Someone You Trust
summary: Tips for having supportive conversations.
body: Sharing what you're going through can feel overwhelming. This article gently guides readers through preparing for a conversation with someone they trust.
author: Support Team

title: Learning to Listen to Myself
summary: A personal reflection on noticing feelings and trusting inner signals.
body: For a long time, I ignored small feelings that something wasn't right. Over time, I learned to honour those feelings and seek support.
author: Guest Writer

title: Why Community Matters
summary: How a supportive environment made a difference in someone's journey.
body: Having people who listen without judgment changed the way I approached challenges. Community support helped me feel less alone.
author: Community Member

title: Small Steps Count Too
summary: A reminder that progress doesn’t have to be big to be meaningful.
body: I used to think change had to be dramatic. But gentle, consistent steps made the biggest difference over time.
author: Guest Writer

title: Finding Calm in Busy Moments
summary: Simple grounding practices that helped me feel more present.
body: I found comfort in small rituals—breathing deeply, stepping outside briefly, or sitting quietly with tea.
author: Wellbeing Contributor

title: When Asking for Help Felt Possible
summary: A story about reaching out during a difficult time.
body: I didn't know what to expect when I first reached out, but I found someone kind on the other side.
author: Guest Blogger

title: Learning to Rest Without Guilt
summary: Honouring the need for rest after emotional exhaustion.
body: Rest used to feel like a luxury. Now I see it as part of healing and reconnecting with myself.
author: Wellbeing Writer

title: The Importance of Kind Words
summary: How gentle communication supported my healing.
body: Small affirmations and patience from those around me made difficult days feel more manageable.
author: Community Member

title: Moments of Clarity
summary: A short story about recognising change.
body: There was a day when I realised I deserved peace. That moment shaped my future choices.
author: Guest Writer

title: The First Time I Felt Safe Again
summary: A gentle reflection on reconnecting with safety.
body: It wasn’t a single event, but a series of small experiences that helped me feel grounded again.
author: Anonymous

title: Hope in Unexpected Places
summary: Reflecting on moments of hope during recovery.
body: Hope showed up quietly—in conversations, in small acts of care, and in the feeling of being understood.
author: Community Member

title: What a Trauma-Informed Approach Really Means
summary: A gentle explanation of trauma-informed care and how it shapes the way support services listen, respond, and walk alongside survivors.
body:
When support is trauma-informed, it recognises that people may be carrying invisible wounds. Instead of asking, "What is wrong with you?" it asks, "What may have happened to you, and how can we support you safely?" This approach centres choice, consent, and emotional safety. It avoids pressure, sudden changes, or judgmental responses. In practice, trauma-informed care looks like giving people time to decide what feels right, explaining each step clearly, and respecting when they need to pause.

For community members, being trauma-informed can mean using softer language, allowing silence in conversations, and not pushing for details. For organisations, it means designing services that minimise re-traumatisation: clear information, private spaces, and staff who are trained to respond calmly and kindly. No one has to be "strong" or "ready" all at once — a trauma-informed approach makes room for people to arrive exactly as they are.
author: Support Team

title: Creating Safer Spaces in Community Settings
summary: Practical ideas for making community spaces feel safer, more welcoming, and more responsive to people who may be carrying difficult experiences.
body:
A safer space is not a perfect space; it is a space that tries to reduce harm and increase care. Community halls, clinics, churches, campuses, and workplaces can all become safer when people think intentionally about how others might be feeling when they walk in. Simple changes can help: clear signage, warm welcomes, private corners for confidential conversations, and visible information about support services.

Safer spaces also rely on how people interact. Staff and volunteers can practise active listening, ask for consent before starting sensitive conversations, and acknowledge when they do not have all the answers. Having clear, visible guidelines against discrimination and harassment sends a message that everyone deserves respect. When someone shares something personal, a gentle response — "Thank you for trusting me with this" — can make a big difference.
author: Community Outreach Team

title: When Online Support Feels Easier Than Speaking Out Loud
summary: Exploring why some people prefer chats, messages, or emails when reaching out, and how to use online tools in safer ways.
body:
For many, typing a message feels gentler than saying the words out loud. Online support can offer privacy, distance, and time to think. It can be accessed from a phone or computer, without needing to travel or explain where you are going. This can be especially helpful when someone feels anxious, unsure, or worried about being overheard.

At the same time, it is important to consider digital safety. Using private browsing where possible, clearing chat histories if it is safe to do so, and using secure passwords can all help. If someone is using a shared device, they may want to log out of accounts and avoid saving passwords. Online platforms can never be completely risk-free, but with small steps and a thoughtful approach, they can become a meaningful way to receive kind, calm support when speaking feels too hard.
author: Digital Support Team

title: Working Together: How Services Coordinate Support
summary: An overview of how different services — health, legal, community, and shelters — can work together to offer more joined-up care.
body:
Support is rarely the work of a single person or organisation. In many communities, healthcare workers, legal advisors, social workers, shelters, and grassroots groups collaborate, even informally, to help people navigate complex situations. When this coordination works well, a person does not have to retell their story many times or chase information alone.

This article explains how referrals can work, what consent means in this context, and why you should always have the right to ask what information is being shared and with whom. It also acknowledges that systems are not perfect: delays, misunderstandings, and resource gaps happen. Even so, multi-sector collaboration remains an important goal, because no single service can meet every need on its own. You deserve clear communication and to feel that people are working with you, not just about you.
author: Multi-Disciplinary Team

title: The Self-Care Habit That Surprised Me
summary: A tiny routine that made a big difference during my week.
body:
This week, my only self-care goal was to drink a glass of water before checking my phone in the morning. Surprisingly, it made my whole day feel calmer.

Tiny acts can be real acts of care — especially when life feels heavy.
author: Wellness Blogger

title: Courage Found Me Before I Found It
summary: A moment where courage appeared quietly rather than suddenly.
body:
I didn’t wake up feeling brave. Courage showed up when I decided to take one small step instead of doing nothing.

It wasn’t loud — it was steady, quiet, and just enough.
author: Anonymous

title: The Message I Still Reread When I Need Strength
summary: How one encouraging message became a reminder that I wasn’t alone.
body:
A friend once texted me, “You’re doing better than you think.” I saved the message, and months later, I still reread it on hard days.

Sometimes encouragement lasts far longer than the moment it’s given.
author: Supportive Friend

title: The Day Someone Truly Listened
summary: A short moment that reminded me how healing it is to be heard.
body:
I didn’t need advice — I just needed someone to sit with me and listen. They didn’t rush my words or try to fix anything.

That simple listening helped more than anything else.
author: Anonymous

title: The One Mindful Exercise That Actually Helped
summary: A simple grounding technique that made me feel present again.
body:
I tried focusing on what I could see, hear, and touch around me. It didn’t solve everything, but it slowed my racing thoughts.

Mindfulness, I learned, works best when practiced gently.
author: Mindfulness Blogger

title: A Small Sign That My Recovery Was Working
summary: A single unexpected moment helped me recognise progress.
body:
I laughed — genuinely — for the first time in months. It wasn’t planned. It wasn’t forced. It was the kind of moment that reminded me that recovery happens slowly, then all at once.

Small signs matter.
author: Recovery Writer

title: What Reflection Taught Me About Myself
summary: A brief reflection on noticing my own growth.
body:
I took a moment to look back at how I reacted to things a year ago, a month ago, even a week ago.

Seeing how much I’d grown made me realise that reflection isn’t about the past — it’s about understanding how far I’ve come.
author: Reflective Contributor

title: Understanding Confidentiality and Its Limits
summary: A clear, gentle explanation of what confidentiality usually means in support settings, and when information might need to be shared.
body:
Confidentiality is an important part of feeling safe enough to talk. Many services will protect your privacy and not share your information without your consent. However, there are times when they may be required to share certain details, especially if there is an immediate risk to your life or someone else’s. This can feel worrying, so it helps to know about it in advance.

A trauma-informed approach means explaining confidentiality clearly at the beginning of a conversation: what is kept private, what might be shared, and how those decisions are made. You always have the right to ask questions like, "Who will see this information?" or "What happens if I tell you this?" Knowing your rights does not remove all uncertainty, but it can restore some sense of control. Support should never feel like a trick; you deserve honesty and transparency about how your information is handled.
author: Legal Support Team

title: The First Time I Felt Truly Listened To
summary: A short reflection on how one kind conversation shifted the way I saw support.
body:
I still remember sitting across from someone who didn’t rush me. They didn’t ask for every detail or press for a clear plan. They simply said, "You’re not alone, and we can take this one step at a time." For the first time in a long while, I felt that my feelings were valid — not too much, not too confusing, just real.

What helped most wasn’t perfect advice. It was their calm tone, their patience when I struggled to find words, and the way they checked in: "Do you want to pause?" That moment didn’t fix everything, but it gave me enough strength to keep looking for support that felt like that — gentle, steady, and honest.
author: Anonymous

title: Small Routines That Help Me Feel Grounded
summary: How a few simple habits help me find moments of calm when life feels heavy.
body:
On the days when my thoughts feel loud, I lean on small routines instead of big expectations. A slow cup of tea, a short walk outside, or writing down three things I did well — even if they seem tiny — can make the day feel less overwhelming. None of these routines erase what I’m carrying, but they remind me that I still exist beyond my experiences.

If you are trying to build your own routines, it’s okay to start very small. One deep breath before you unlock your phone. Stretching your shoulders once an hour. Keeping a kind sentence in your notes app to reread when you need it. Healing doesn’t always look like huge changes; sometimes it looks like giving yourself a few gentle minutes that belong only to you.
author: Wellbeing Contributor

title: Why I Chose Online Chat Instead of Calling
summary: A personal story about reaching out for help in the way that felt most manageable.
body:
When I first thought about asking for help, the idea of speaking on the phone made my chest tighten. I was scared I would freeze, or cry, or not know how to explain anything. Finding an online chat option changed things. Typing felt slower and more controlled; I could pause, delete, and rephrase without feeling like I was wasting anyone’s time.

The person on the other side of the screen didn’t rush me. They reminded me I could stop at any point and that I didn’t have to share more than I wanted. That experience taught me that there isn’t one "right" way to reach out. What matters most is choosing the path that feels safest for you in that moment — whether that’s chat, email, phone, or sitting with someone you trust in person.
author: Anonymous

title: Learning That My Reactions Make Sense
summary: How understanding trauma responses helped me feel less "too sensitive" and more human.
body:
For a long time I called myself "dramatic" or "too much" because loud noises or certain conversations made my body react more strongly than other people’s. Only later, after speaking with a counsellor, did I learn about trauma responses — how the body can stay alert long after difficult events have passed.

Hearing that my reactions were understandable took away some of the shame I was carrying. It didn’t remove every hard moment, but it gave me new language: instead of "I’m broken," I could say, "My body is trying to protect me." That shift helped me treat myself with a little more patience. If you notice strong reactions in yourself, you’re not failing; your body may be doing its best to keep you safe with the tools it has.
author: Guest Writer

title: Hope Looked Different Than I Expected
summary: A reflection on how hope can show up quietly in everyday moments, not just in big milestones.
body:
I used to think hope would arrive as a single big event — a clear answer, a final resolution, a dramatic turning point. Instead, it crept in slowly. It looked like being able to sleep a little more deeply. It sounded like a friend checking in, "How are you, really?" It felt like noticing that I could go a whole afternoon without that tight knot in my stomach.

On this journey, I’m learning that hope is not pretending everything is fine. It’s acknowledging what is hard while still believing that small shifts are possible. Some days, hope is simply opening a resource page, saving a helpline number, or sending a message to someone kind. Those actions may seem small from the outside, but inside, they can be proof that you haven’t given up on yourself.
author: Community Member

title: Why Awareness Starts With Listening
summary: Awareness is not only about statistics — it begins with truly hearing people’s experiences in their own time and their own words.
body:
When we talk about awareness, many people think of campaigns or public events. But meaningful awareness often starts in quiet moments — simply listening without rushing, without judgment. When someone shares a difficult experience, they’re giving a small piece of their truth. Responding with patience, kindness, and curiosity can open doors that numbers alone cannot.

Awareness grows when communities learn to notice the subtle ways people ask for help: changes in behaviour, hesitation in speech, or a shift in energy. Building a culture of awareness means encouraging conversations that are gentle, honest, and safe for everyone involved.
author: Awareness Team

title: How Support Systems Can Reduce Isolation
summary: Support networks, even small ones, can help people feel grounded and less alone during overwhelming moments.
body:
Support doesn’t always come from large organisations. Sometimes it begins with a friend who checks in consistently, a neighbour who listens, or a community member who shares supportive resources. When people feel seen and understood, the sense of isolation begins to fade.

Effective support systems honour boundaries, offer choices, and allow space for hesitation. They never pressure or demand. Instead, they provide gentle encouragement and ensure people feel safe enough to speak at their own pace.
author: Care Network

title: Learning the Language of Emotional Safety
summary: Emotional safety is learned through small, intentional communication habits that help people feel respected and understood.
body:
The way we speak to one another shapes how safe we feel. Educational efforts around emotional safety highlight simple but powerful practices: asking for consent before discussing sensitive topics, clarifying intentions, using calmer tones, and giving people time to respond.

Education is not about perfection; it is about learning together. When communities commit to learning the language of care, they create environments where more people feel able to open up and seek help.
author: Learning Circle

title: The Strength in Sharing Personal Journeys
summary: Stories can foster empathy and connection while reminding others that healing is not linear.
body:
Every story shared makes space for someone else to feel less alone. Personal journeys, whether spoken publicly or shared privately with a trusted person, help others understand that healing is complex. No two paths are the same.

When stories are treated gently — without pressure, assumptions, or judgment — they can become powerful tools for connection. They remind us that courage often looks like small steps.
author: Community Writer

title: A Gentle Guide to Understanding Your Legal Rights
summary: A simplified explanation of how legal protections work and what people can expect when seeking help.
body:
Legal processes can feel intimidating, especially when emotions are already heavy. This guide offers a calm, step-by-step overview of common protections, privacy considerations, and what to expect when speaking with a legal adviser.

You do not need to know everything at once. You have the right to ask questions, request pauses, or bring along someone who helps you feel more grounded.
author: Legal Support Team

title: Creating Everyday Safety Plans
summary: Simple, practical steps people can take to feel safer in their daily routines.
body:
Safety planning isn’t only for emergencies — it can help people navigate everyday life with more confidence. This includes identifying safe contacts, planning transportation options, and knowing where supportive spaces are located.

The goal is not fear, but preparedness and empowerment. Each plan is personal and should be built around what feels safest for the individual.
author: Safety Educator

title: How Communities Become Supportive Ecosystems
summary: A look at how local groups, leaders, and neighbours can help create a culture of care.
body:
Communities become safer when people learn to look out for one another. Supportive ecosystems develop when leaders encourage kindness, when programs are accessible, and when information is shared openly and respectfully.

Building such a community takes time, but every small act contributes: offering help, sharing resources, or simply acknowledging someone’s feelings without judgment.
author: Community Builder

title: Digital Safety for Sensitive Conversations
summary: Tips for keeping online conversations more private and secure.
body:
Online communication can be a helpful way to reach out, especially when speaking aloud feels overwhelming. But digital privacy matters. Using strong passwords, avoiding shared devices, and clearing chat histories can help protect sensitive messages.

This article also covers private browsing, secure apps, and knowing what information is safe to share online.
author: Digital Advocate

title: Finding Small Moments of Calm
summary: A reflection on gentle grounding practices for emotional wellbeing.
body:
Wellbeing is built from small, manageable practices: deep breaths, grounding exercises, short walks, quiet time, or writing down feelings without judgment.

This article provides several simple grounding techniques that can help steady emotions during stressful moments.
author: Wellbeing Coach

title: Redefining Self-Care as Permission, Not Pressure
summary: Self-care isn’t about perfection — it’s about giving yourself permission to rest and recover.
body:
Self-care is often misunderstood as indulgence or strict routines. But for many, it simply means allowing yourself to pause, breathe, and take small steps toward comfort.

This article explores gentle self-care without pressure, expectations, or comparison to others.
author: Self-Care Writer

title: Healing as a Non-Linear Journey
summary: Healing often moves in waves — with steps forward, pauses, and moments of return.
body:
Many people imagine healing as a straight path, but it’s more like a cycle of progress, reflection, and growth. This article reassures readers that setbacks are normal and do not erase the steps already taken.

Healing is personal. You set the pace.
author: Healing Support Team

title: Understanding Emotional Overload
summary: A gentle explanation of why emotions sometimes feel too big and what can help.
body:
Emotional overload can come from past experiences, current stress, or a mix of both. This article explains grounding tools, normalises emotional sensitivity, and encourages seeking support.

You don’t have to navigate emotions alone — support is available.
author: Mental Health Educator

title: When Hope Arrives Quietly
summary: Hope sometimes appears in small signs rather than major breakthroughs.
body:
Hope doesn’t always look dramatic. Sometimes it’s the first deep breath in a while, a kind message from a friend, or the feeling of being less weighed down than yesterday.

This article explores recognising small signs of hope in everyday life.
author: Hope Writer

title: Why Online Support Helps When Speaking Is Hard
summary: Online chats and messages can offer a gentler way to ask for help.
body:
For many people, typing feels safer than speaking out loud. Online support gives space to think, pause, and express feelings gradually.

This article discusses how to use online tools safely and what to expect when reaching out digitally.
author: Digital Care Team

title: What Trauma-Informed Support Looks Like in Practice
summary: A simple explanation of what trauma-informed care means in everyday interactions.
body:
Trauma-informed care means supporting people in ways that reduce fear, increase choice, and respect personal boundaries.

This article outlines the core principles and how communities can adopt them.
author: Trauma-Informed Educator

title: The Moment I Noticed Awareness Begins Small
summary: A short reflection on how one conversation shifted my understanding of what awareness truly means.
body:
I always assumed awareness meant big events, posters, or powerful speeches. But one day, a friend simply asked me, “Are you okay? You seem quieter than usual.” That small question made me realise awareness begins when we choose to notice each other.

It reminded me that change doesn’t always come from campaigns — sometimes it starts with one person paying gentle, human attention.
author: Community Member

title: The Support I Didn’t Know I Needed
summary: A story about discovering comfort in small, consistent check-ins.
body:
I used to think support meant dramatic interventions. But the support that changed me was simple: a friend who checked in every few days with a soft, “Thinking of you.” No pressure, no expectations.

Those messages didn’t solve everything, but they reminded me that I mattered — and sometimes, that’s enough to keep going.
author: Anonymous

title: How One Conversation Taught Me Emotional Boundaries
summary: A personal moment that helped me understand why emotional boundaries matter.
body:
Someone once told me, “You don’t have to answer that if you don’t want to.” It was such a small sentence, but it taught me more about emotional education than any workshop.

It reminded me that feeling safe sometimes begins with being given a choice — especially when talking about difficult experiences.
author: Learning Contributor

title: Sharing My Story One Sentence at a Time
summary: Healing began when I allowed myself to share only what felt safe.
body:
I used to think I had to tell everything at once. But then someone told me, “Take your time. Say only what feels okay.” That changed everything.

My story didn’t come out in a single moment — it came in waves. And that was enough.
author: Anonymous

title: The First Time Someone Explained My Rights Clearly
summary: A short experience about how clarity can ease fear.
body:
I sat in a small office, nervous and unsure. The legal adviser noticed and gently said, “Let’s go step by step. You stop me anytime.”

That patience mattered. Clear, simple explanations made a frightening process feel manageable. For the first time, I felt like the system wasn’t against me — it was something I could navigate.
author: Legal Help User

title: A Small Plan That Helped Me Feel Safe Again
summary: A personal moment about building a simple, everyday safety plan.
body:
A counsellor once asked me, “What makes you feel safer during the day?” I didn’t have an answer then, but we made a small plan together — saving emergency contacts, choosing safer routes, and identifying one trusted person.

It wasn’t dramatic, but knowing I had a plan helped my body relax again.
author: Safety Planner

title: The Day My Community Showed Up for Me
summary: A short story about how community support can come from unexpected places.
body:
I expected to walk this journey alone. Instead, my community surprised me. A neighbour offered a ride when I needed it most. A local group shared resources without asking for details. A friend cooked a meal and left it at my door.

Those gestures reminded me that healing is easier when a community quietly surrounds you.
author: Community Member

title: Why I Started Using a Safer App for Support
summary: A reflection on learning digital safety through lived experience.
body:
I used to message from shared devices without thinking much about it, until someone explained how easily messages could be accessed. I learned to use private modes, secure passwords, and apps with disappearing messages.

It wasn’t about fear — it was about giving myself more control.
author: Digital Learner

title: My Five-Minute Daily Reset
summary: A small grounding routine that helps me stay centred.
body:
Every afternoon, I take five minutes to breathe, stretch, and reset. It’s simple, but it gives me a moment that belongs only to me.

Those few minutes don’t fix everything, but they give me a sense of calm I didn’t have before.
author: Wellbeing Contributor

title: What Self-Care Looked Like for Me This Week
summary: A real weekly snapshot of gentle self-care moments.
body:
This week, self-care meant saying no to one thing, resting for an hour, and letting myself cry without apologising. None of it was glamorous — but all of it felt honest.

I’m learning that self-care is less about rituals and more about permission.
author: Self-Care Writer

title: When I Realised Healing Isn’t Linear
summary: A short story about noticing progress during a difficult week.
body:
I had a setback last week and felt like I was back at the beginning. But a supporter reminded me, “A step back doesn’t erase any of your steps forward.”

That helped me breathe again — healing doesn’t stop because of a hard day.
author: Healing Journey Contributor

title: The First Time I Understood My Emotions
summary: A brief moment that helped me name and understand my feelings.
body:
Someone once told me, “Your emotions aren’t the enemy — they’re signals.” That sentence changed how I approached my mental health.

Understanding my emotions didn’t make them disappear, but it made them feel less frightening.
author: Mental Health Blogger

title: A Quiet Moment That Gave Me Hope
summary: Hope arrived for me in the form of a gentle morning.
body:
One morning I realised I could breathe more easily than the day before. Nothing extraordinary happened — but something in me felt lighter.

That gentle shift reminded me that hope doesn’t always arrive loudly.
author: Hope Contributor

title: How Online Support Helped Me Share at My Own Pace
summary: A short reflection on why typing felt safer for me than talking.
body:
Typing gave me space to think, rephrase, and pause without feeling embarrassed. It allowed me to reach out without needing to speak out loud.

Online support became a bridge — a gentle place between silence and conversation.
author: Online Support User

title: The First Time Someone Responded in a Trauma-Informed Way
summary: A short, meaningful moment of feeling genuinely safe during a hard conversation.
body:
I told someone a small piece of my story, expecting pressure or questions. Instead, they said, “Thank you for trusting me. Take your time.”

That gentle response made me feel safe in a way I hadn’t felt in a long time. It taught me what trauma-informed support truly looks like.
author: Trauma-Informed Advocate
